keyList.description: Scale degree numbers from 1 through 7.
Octave number 0 through 9, with the middle C octave being 4 (**degree data only).
Scale degree is raised (one semitone) from default position in scale.
Scale degree is raised by two semitones from default position in scale.
(minus sign) Scale degree is lowered (one semitone) from default position in scale.
Scale degree is lowered two semitones from default position in scale.
Scale degree is approached by a rising interval (previous note is lower).  When *refined is enabled, this means approached up by step.
Scale degree is approached by a rising interval (previous note is lower).  When *refined is enabled, this means approached up by leap.
Scale degree is approached by a falling interval (previous note is higher).  When *refined is enabled, this means approached down by step.
Scale degree is approached by a falling interval (previous note is higher).  When *refined is enabled, this means approached down by leap.
Scale degree is departed by a rising interval (next note is higher).  When *refined is enabled, this means departed up by step.
(two single quotes) Scale degree is departed by a rising interval (next note is higher).  When *refined is enabled, this means departed up by leap.
(comma) Scale degree is departed by a falling interval (next note is lower).  When *refined is enabled, this means departed down by step.
(two commas) Scale degree is departed by a falling interval (next note is lower).  When *refined is enabled, this means departed down by leap.
The following scale degrees are in reference to C major.
The following scale degrees are in reference to D minor.
In a minor key, the 7th scale degree is a major 7th above the tonic. (7th scale degree is in the harmonic minor scale)
In a minor key, the 7th scale degree is a minor 7th above the tonic. (7th scale degree is in the natural minor scale)
Scale degree is in a minor mode (use **minnat and **minhar to distinguish between natural and harmonic minor).
Scale degree is in a major mode.
Suppress display of the scale degree component to the immediate left of the y (melodic approach, melodic departure, and in the future after degrees and octaves).
Suppress display of the entire scale degree token.
Recommended RDF markers.
Phrase marking.

Key signature that the scale degrees are in reference to.  This is the same as the key designations in **kern data, such as "c:" for C minor, "*B-:" for B♭" major, and "*f#:" for F♮ major.  Modal keys are not yet implemented.
Display degree alterations as arrows.
Stop Displaying degree alterations as arrows.
Display the scale degrees in an italic font.
Stop displaying the scale degrees in italic font.
Display scale degrees within boxes.
Stop displaying scale degrees within boxes.
Display scale degrees within circles.
Stop displaying scale degrees within circles.
Set the color of the scale degrees to dodgerblue.  Any SVG color descriptor can be used. Use *color:black to return to the default color (black).
Show melodic approach and departure information. (default)
Hide melodic approach and departure information.
Display the scale degrees at 80%.  The size may also be one of the following symbolic sizes: smallest (60%), smaller (75%), small (89%), normal (100%), large (120%), larger (150%), largest (200%).
Display a hat (caret, circumflex) above the scale degree.
Stop displaying hats above scale degrees.
Display the scale degrees in an italic font.
Stop displaying the scale degrees in italic font.
Approach and departure contour is gross (up/down by any interval). (default output of deg tool)
Approach and departure contour is refined (up/down by step or leap).
Scale degrees displayed in the natural minor mode (7th degree is a minor 7th above the tonic).
Scale degrees in reference to the harmonic minor mode when in a minor key(default: 7th degree is a major 7th above the tonic).
